dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: cold, windy morning in Texas. Except for one car -- an old white Nash that belongs to ANDY FANNER, the night- watchman, the square is deserted. Wind blows the curling dust down the empty main street, past the picture show, a laundry, a dinky beauty parlor, a grocery store. A black Chevrolet pickup, vintage 1941, is coughing its way up the long road toward the square. ’S PI iP Cl CITY SQUAR: — DAWN 2 SONNY CRAWFORD riddles intently with the choke, trying to keep the pickup running. The radio is on but the sound of the motor all but drowms it out. In front of the picture show, the pickup dies and the popular 1951 song fills the cab. Sonny relaxes, yawns, peers at the movie posters a moment. (He wears a Levi jacket and his hair is neatly combed -- except for a cowlick at the back, which sticks straight up; now and then, he tries to smoot it down.) Before hitting the starter again, he blows into his hands. The pickup grinds for a minute, then kicks off -- Sonny races the engine before moving on. At the red light he looks over at Fanner, who is asleep in the front seat; his feet, in heavy brogans, are visible, propped on the dashboard, A pickup with three horses in it goes through the light. Sonny starts to turn toward the pool- hall, but far down the street sees a figure sweeping, and drives that way instead. BILLY is sweeping down the white line, toward the city limits sign, ribbons of dust around the broom. (He too wears a frayed Levi jacket -- also an old red baseball cap.) Sonny pulls up beside him and taps his horn. Billy looks up, grins happily, trots around and gets into the cab. Sonny makes a sweeping U-turn, reaches over and turns Billy’s cap around backwards. Billy grins. The song is over and an announcer comes on: COTTONSEED CLARK (v.o.) Folks, ol’ Cottonseed Clark talkin’ at you -- we’ll get some more good music out to you in a minute but first let me say a word or two about these wonderful Purina Poultry Chows...

Sonny parks in front of the poolhall; he and Billy hurry in -- the dust blowing. Lr POO: - DAWN 5 Near the front, there’s a counter, a small candy case, and a green Dr. Pepper machine. SAM ("the lion") is bent over the snooker table, brushing the felt care- fully and slowly. (He wears an old mackinaw and a pair of thoroughly run-down sheepskin house shoes. ) He winces at the inrush of cold wind, but gives the boys no more than a glance. As he bends to brush again he is seized with a coughing fit and has to stop brush- ing until the fit subsides, going behind the counter for his cough medicine. During Sam’s seizure, Billy picks up a piece of pool- chalk and ildy begins to lick it. Sonny gets himself a Peanut Pattie and a Dr. Pepper; puts a nickel on the counter and goes over to stand right in front of the old, open-burner gas stove to warm himself. Sam starts to roll a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (fondly) Well, you’ve already spent a dime today an’ you ain’t even had a decent breakfast. Sam holds out his hand for the chalk Billy is licking. Billy, his tongue quite green, hands it to him, and comes to stand next to Sonny, who grabs his cap. Sam watches as Billy lunges for it and Sonny feints and throws it across the room. - Billy goes to get it.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (lighting cigarette) I’m surprised you had the nerve to come in this mornin’, after the stompin’ y’all took.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: (munching candy) Coulda been worse. Sonny idly takes a cue stick, as the sound of very loud MUFFLERS is HEARD. Billy looks nervously outside as Sonny does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ABILENE is seen getting out of his souped-up, shiny Mercury, wearing sunglasses.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (during the above) You can say that ‘bout nearly everything.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (continuing) A few football teams’ve had some luck with tackling -- keeps the other team from scoring quite i so often.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Sounds too rough for me. Abilene comes in, gives them a nod, unzips his cover- alls and hangs them on a nail. (His flannel shirt has pearl buttons, and his gabardine pants are well- pressed.) Billy begins to sweep along one side of the poolhall, restlessly.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: You don’t even care if it was your last game -- you ain’t ever gonna get stomped for your own high school again -- where’s your school spirit?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: (glancing at : Abilence) i Don‘t know -~

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: | (to Sonny) You workin’ today?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: (nods) The truck’s bein’ greased. Sam reaches beneath the counter and lays Abilence’s ivory-banded, jointed cue on the counter. Abilene lays his sunglasses on the counter and Sam automatically puts them in a drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abilene looks at Sam as he assembles his cue. Sam looks at him, gets the point, takes out an old but well-stuffed wallet, and hands Abilene a fifty dollar bill. Both are quite cool when their eyes meet.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (to Sonny) See -- this here’s what I get for bettin’ on my hometown ball team -- oughta have better sense.

dialogues.speaker: ABILENE
dialogues.text: ¢putting his cue together) Wouldn’t hurt if you had a better hometown. Billy sweeps to the door, scared of Abilene; he goes out as Abilene comes by Sonny, who holds the cue awk- wardly, wishing he’d never picked it up. Abilene adds the fifty dollar bill to a huge wad held together by a money clip.

dialogues.speaker: ABILENE
dialogues.text: (continuing) ~*~ Mind pointin’ that at the floor A till I get by? I don’t want my eye poked out. Sonny hurriedly points the cue at the floor.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Don’t let Billy get too far away, will ya, son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: | You’re a damn sight more dangerous 1 in a poolhall than you are on a foolball field. Ever heard of tackling? Sonny puts up his cue. Abilene breaks a rack of red- balls, moves smoothly around the table. Sam starts to cough again and Sonny goes out.

dialogues.speaker: T. POOLHALL
dialogues.text: Billy is three doors away, sweeping at the swirling dust. As Sonny catches up with him, a pickup stops in the mid- ddle of the street. THREE YOUNG ROUGHNECKS huddle in the back, their coat collars turned up. One is DUANE i ” JACKSON, who jumps out quickly, holding an old lunch pail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Hey, Duane!

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: Boy, I froze my ass last night. He and Sonny grab Billy, each getting an arm. As they hustle him back to the poolhall, the DRIVER of the pickup honks his horn at them, and yells out his window.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Why the fuck can’t you kids learn to tackle?! At a loss for a reply, the boys look at each other, hustl Billy back to the poolhall, and turn to go. Sam leans out the door with a green change-sack in his hand, yells over the wind.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: How about takin’ Genevieve some change -- since you’re going? He heaves the sack underhanded -- Duane leaps up and catches it one-handed, trous along, fades, and throws a short pass to Sonny, who catches it, stops, stoops, and centers the sack back to Duane. They go on down the street, spiritedly throwing the sack back and forth between them. TWO MECHANICS are standing near the cafe, one of them morosely kicking at the tire of his car. They observe the boys without changing their poker-faced expressions.

dialogues.speaker: 1ST MECHANIC
dialogues.text: Look at that, Larry. They can catch.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (slow drawl) Feisty sonsofbitches, ain’t they? Wisht they could tackle.

dialogues.speaker: 1ST MECHANIC
dialogues.text: Or do somethin’ useful. Team weren’t worth a kiss-my-ass this year. The boys stop and frown, but the two men sullenly stare them down, so they g6 into the cafe, which is rundown on the outside -- much of the paint peeling off, the sign not hanging straight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rev. 10/2/70 : 6. 9 INT. CAFE — DAY 9

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Small, clean and cozy, with bright linoleum, four red leatherette booths, several stools, and a shiny juke- box, which is playing. TWO COWBOYS are sitting at the counter, a DRILLER with a toothpick in his mouth is at the cash register, and some ROUGHNECKS occupy two of the booths. Duane tosses the sack one final time, but in catching it Sonny almost runs into GENEVIEVE, carry- ing several plates of sausage and eggs in her hands. Stepping back, the swinging door to the kitchen hits her on the behind; she fixes them with a fond but stern eye.

dialogues.speaker: GENEVIEVE
dialogues.text: All right, you boys, knock it off -- I got problems enough without you playing the game over again. A cowboy looks around at them with disgust. * Sonny smiles at her and puts the sack on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: We coulda run off to Mexico with this, you know. The boys laugh and stand in front of the jukebox as =, Genevieve waits on tables. Sonny tosses a quarter up i and catches it, studying the selections. When he tos- ~ ses it up again, Genevieve catches it.

dialogues.speaker: GENEVIEVE
dialogues.text: (going into kitchen) Down-payment on breakfast. Let somebody prosperous play the jukebox.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: (grinning) Nobody prosperous would eat here. Sonny laughs, and so does Duane. They take a booth and empty their pockets, pooling their money -- very little.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Well, I ain’t so hungry.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: I am! (a little anxiously) Say, y’ want the pickup first tonight? Co (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Naw.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: I oughtn’t to get it first ever! Saturday night -- it’s half yours.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Aw, go ahead. DUANE. (relieved) You sure? A lanky COWBOY stops by their table on the way out, looks down at them, a toothpick in his mouth. The boys don’t notice him.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Sure I’m sure. Anyways, I got lots of deliveries -- have to go clear to Ranger this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: (noticing the cowboy ) Be lucky to get back in time for the second show. Duane follows Sonny’s look to the cowboy, whose expres-— sion is somber, almost grave. After another silent moment, he shakes his head, says "Tsk," returns the toothpick to his mouth, and walks on out, never once changing his expression. The boys look at each other hopelessly.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. TEXAS ROADS — DAY 10 Sonny drives out of town in an old, battered, green International truck, with "FARLEY BUTANE AND PROPANE" lettered on the cab. It passes the city limits sign, goes up the long road between pastures of leafless, black mesquite, and over empty, windblown ridges. The country looks very cold, empty -- the grey ridges stretch far away. He SINGS with the RADIO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rev. 9/24/70 a1 12 13 14 . UNTRY _F. = ¥ 11 Sonny is filling a butane tank. The door of the truck is open and the RADIO is playing a hillbilly hit. A couple of chow dogs are BARKING at him from behind a fence. cuUT TO: EXT. cc [OW _-. NIGHT 12 The square is empty except for six or eight cars parked in front of the picture show. There is no one at the ticket window, so Sonny just goes in. INT. PICTURE SHOW LOBBY — NIGHT 13 MISS MOSEY is scraping out the popcorn machine; she looks up and smiles at Sonny.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MOSEY
dialogues.text: My goodness, Sonny, Frank eughtn’t to work you so late on weekends --

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: That’s what I keep telling ‘im.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MOSEY
dialogues.text: You ain’t got in in time for the comedy in three weeks. Hope you don’t want no popcorn, ‘cause there ain’t none. Sonny hands her a dollar and takes a package of gum.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MOSEY
dialogues.text: (continuing) Missed the newsreel, too. And the main show’s done started -- I’1l just change you thirty cents. Pic ES! = 14 There are only slightly more than a score of people seated inside. CHARLENE and MARLENE DUGGS are sitting on the aisle, near the front. Sonny comes down, taps Marlene on the shoulder; the two scoot over a seat and he sits next to Charlene, who wears his football jacket. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHARLENE
dialogues.text: (not whispering) I decided you had a wreck. Sonny holds out the gum. The girls instantly take sticks and pop them into their mouths almost simul- taneously. Sonny nudges Charlene and gestures with his head. The two get up and move toward the back. They pass Billy sitting alone, the broom beside him, his expression one of deep content as he watches the movie. Charlene turns to be kissed, then stops to take the chewing gum out of her mouth. They kiss, Sonny keep- ing his eye on the movie. Charlene sighs, leans back, and languidly puts the chewing gum back in her mouth. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ed 14

dialogues.speaker: CHARLENE
dialogues.text: Guess what?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: (not looking at her) What?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLENE
dialogues.text: It’s our anniversary.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: (looks at her) What?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLENE
dialogues.text: We been going steady a year tonight.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: (pouts) You shoulda got me some anniversary present.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Well, you can have another stick of gum -- that’s all I got on me. He notices Duane and JACY FARROW come in a front exit.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLENE
dialogues.text: You can give me a dollar, too - that’s what it cost me and Marlene for the show. Sonny hands her the gum only, as Duane and Jacy sit down just in front of them, nodding as they do.

dialogues.speaker: JACY
dialogues.text: (whispering gaily) Hi, what you all doing back here in the dark? Sonny looks at her wistfully, with yearning. Charlene frowns and begins to pop her finger joints, sitting up, very prim and proper as jacy and Duane begin to kiss passionately.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLENE
dialogues.text: I don’t see why they should get the pickup first all of the time - all they wanna do is neck anyway - Why do they even come to the show? Sonny tries to watch the movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam is opening the front doors of the theatre as a few people straggle out. Billy is already sweeping. Sonny and Charlene exit, Marlene right behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Mosey struggles with a large poster that is flap- ping in the wind. Sam comes out to help her. Duane and Jacy hold hands and dash off toward her convertible, which is parked across the street. AD LIB "Good nights." Sonny and Charlene start unhappily toward the pickup, not holding hands. Marlene is left waiting at the curb, shivering, as the other couples drive away.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. CITY LAKE — NIGHT 17 Sonny’s pickup stops by the desolate, deserted lakeside -- after a moment the lights go out. SONNY’S_P c = NIGH 18 * Charlene sits close to Sonny -- as steadies should.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLENE
dialogues.text: Crack your window an’ leave the motor running -- it’s still too cold in here. Sonny opens the window a crack. The little light from the radio shows us their faces as a TUNE PLAYS. Charlene takes off the football jacket, and matter-of- factly lifts her sweater, HUMMING along with the radio. Sonny unhooks her bra, removes it, and hangs it on the rear-view mirror. He touches her. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CHARLENE
dialogues.text: Eeh! Your hands are like ice.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: (trying to kid her) I could put.on my gloves. They kiss a while -- then stop. Sonny holds one of her breasts in his hand; both of them are listening to the RADIO. Suddenly Charlene looks at Sonny angrily. |

dialogues.speaker: CHARLENE
dialogues.text: What’s the matter with you? You act plain bored. Sonny is startled, kisses her and abruptly lowers his hand. Charlene catches it at the navel and breaks the kiss.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLENE
dialogues.text: (continuing) Quit! Quit!

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: You said this was our anniversary ~~ let’s do something’ different --

dialogues.speaker: CHARLENE
dialogues.text: I like that -- you cheapskate! You never ever give me a present an’ now you want to go right ahead and get me pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: My God, Charlene -- it was just my hand! Charlene scoots back across the seat, and takes her bra off the rear-view mirror.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLENE
dialogues.text: Yeah, and one thing leads to another -- Momma told me how that old stuff goes -- We’1l have plenty a time for that when we get married.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: (watches her fix her’ bra) You wasn’t no livelier than me. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CHARLENE
dialogues.text: That’s ‘cause you ain’t good- looking enough. You ain’t even got a ducktail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like Van Johnson...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLENE
dialogues.text: Yeah. I’m done late anyway -- * let’s go home ~- Some anniversary. Sonny twists the knob on his steering wheel and stares * at the water.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: If you feel that way, I’d just as soon break up, Charlene --

dialogues.speaker: CHARLENE
dialogues.text: What!?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: (backing up) I don’t want to spoil no more anniversaries for you.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLENE
dialogues.text: That’s the way nice girls get treated in this town! I knew you wasn’t. dependable. (taking off jacket) You wasn’t even in the backfield, either.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: What’s that got to do with it -- ?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLENE
dialogues.text: This jacket’s got a hole in the pocket, but you needn’t as’ me to sew it up. And you can give me back my pictures. I don’t want you showin’ ‘em to a lot of other boys and tellin’ them how hot I am.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: (depressed) You wasn’t very hot.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: INT. CAFE (THRU WINDOW) -— NIGHT Sonny is sitting at the counter eating a cheesburger, wearing his football jacket. ("Co-Captain" stitched across the front in green thread.) Genevieve wipes the counter across from him. . The JUKEBOX is playing quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonny watches Genevieve a little longingly, until she turns to him, comes over.

dialogues.speaker: GENEVIEVE
dialogues.text: I hope you ain’t down in the mouth ‘bout Charlene.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: I ain’t blue about her...

dialogues.speaker: GENEVIEVE
dialogues.text: She didn’t even have a good disposition -- what’re you blue about then?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: (shrugs ) Ain’t nobody to go with in this town. Jacy’s the only pretty girl in school and Duane’s got her.

dialogues.speaker: . GENEVIEVE
dialogues.text: I’d call that his tough luck -- y’don’t have to eat so fast... y’ain’t in a race. Jacy’1l bring him more misery than she’1ll ever be worth. Sonny watches her as he takes a last bite and hands her a ten-dollar bill.

dialogues.speaker: GENEVIEVE
dialogues.text: Your Dad give you this?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) He needs all he’s got. Sonny nervously begins popping toothpicks out of a dispenser. Genevieve makes change. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GENEVIEVE
dialogues.text: Wouldn’t hurt you to take a little something from him once in a while. I don’t know -- you and Duane -- both in a boardinghouse -- him with a mother, you with a father. Don’t seem right. An’ your dad’s takin’ too many pills, you know.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: (nervously) Yeah. Genevieve slaps at his hand to make him let the tooth- * picks alone and he walks over to the jukebox and combs his hair in the reflection.

dialogues.speaker: GENEVIEVE
dialogues.text: (reflective) But then I’m no one to talk. I never got on with Mama -- still don’t.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Say, I hear Dan’s goin’ back to work soon -- I guess you’ll be

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: quittin’ before long. Sonny comes back and gets one more toothpick, as * Genevieve draws herself some coffee.

dialogues.speaker: GENEVIEVE
dialogues.text: Honey, we got four thousand dollars worth of doctor bills to pay -- I’1l probably be making cheesburgers for your grandkids.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Well, see ya tomorrow. * He goes out; she stares after him for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: fo MR. JOHN CECIL is seated cheerfully on the edge of his C 4 desk, a book open in his hand. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rev. 23

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The class is just settling down amid much RUSTLING of books. Duane and Sonny throw punches across the aisle; Jacy has just taken out her mirror, and JOE BOB BLANTON is slicking back his dandruffy blond hair with a comb. LEROY MALONE pops AGNES BEAN’S bra strap loudly; she looks at him fiercely. WINNIE SNIPS and BUD WOOD are also there.

dialogues.speaker: MR. CECIL
dialogues.text: Well, I wonder what my chances are this morning of interesting you kids in John Keats.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: None at all. General laughter; Duane looks for Jacy’s reaction -- she is studying her mouth. Joe Bob raises his hand, seriously.

dialogues.speaker: MR. CECIL
dialogues.text: Joe Bob?

dialogues.speaker: JOE BOB
dialogues.text: I read that poem of this*bout the nightingale, and it didn’t sound so good to me. Sounded like he wanted to be a nightingale.

dialogues.speaker: MR. CECIL
dialogues.text: No, not really -- he --

dialogues.speaker: JOE BOB
dialogues.text: I think it’s silly of all these poets to want to be somethin’ besides what the Lord made ‘em. It’s criticizing the Lord.

dialogues.speaker: MR. CECIL
dialogues.text: I don’t think he wanted to be a nightingale, Joe Bob. Maybe he just wanted to be immortal.

dialogues.speaker: JOE BOB
dialogues.text: (smugly) All you have to do to be immortal is lead a good Christian life. Anybody can do it if they love the Lord. Leroy pops Agnes’ strap again; she takes off her shoe and hits him in the nose with it. Mr. Cecil looks at them fondly. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MR. CECIL
dialogues.text: Maybe so, Joe Bob, maybe so. Here, now let me read you this -- "When old age shall this generation waste Thou shalt remain, in midst of other woe Than ours, a friend to man... " While Mr. Cecil reads, Joe Bob opens his chenistry book, Duane dozes on his arms, Sonny looks out the window at two dogs sniffing around each other on the * front lawn. Jacy studies her mouth, Leroy rubs his * nose. *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The COACH sits in a bridge chair, scratching his hairy gut (part of which is visible under his sweatshirt) ahd spitting tobacco juice into a paper cup. The TEAM, all but exhausted, is running laps around the gym, Joe Bob far to the rear, flopping his arms des- perately. Occasionally, when they pass his chair, the Coach leans over and pops one of them hard with a towel. Bud and KENNY WOOD and Leroy are among them.

dialogues.speaker: COACH
dialogues.text: Run, you little piss-ants. Tough it out! Tough it out! You gotta be men like the rest of us -- ain’t none of you pretty enough to be women... Here --~ Joe Bob! Quit flapping your arms -- you look like a goddamn goose! (spits, strands, still scratching) All right, off the court. If y’all didn’t jack off so much maybe some of you could stay in shape. Come here a minute, Sonny. TOMMY LOGAN comes jogging past and the Coach uncon- sciously pats him on the ass as he goes off the court. Sonny stops in front of him, dribbling a basketball, which the Coach takes and throws casually at Joe Bob, who is still flopping his arms.

dialogues.speaker: COACH
dialogues.text: Do me a favor and I’1l1 do you one.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Sure, Coach. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: COACH
dialogues.text: My old lady’s gotta go to th’ doctor tomorrow, over in Olney -- you know women, always something wrong with ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Yeah, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: COACH
dialogues.text: Well, take it from me. Anyway, I ain’t got time to drive her. You do it for me and I’1l get you out of Civics class.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Be glad to -- best offer I’ve had all day.

dialogues.speaker: COACH
dialogues.text: (walking in) Tell her you got to get back in time for practice, so she won’t stay in there too long. I got bills enough to pay already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rev.

dialogues.speaker: DELETED
dialogues.text: . '¥ ooL, — Y¥ 26 Jacy is driving her convertible, Duane and Sonny with her; the car moves away from school. Other kids’ cars are in b.g.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: (imitating Coach) You know what’s a matter with you 1i’1 piss ants -- !? You ain’t got no school spirit. (belches ) They all laugh. Suddenly with some flamboyance, Sonny bursts into the school SONG.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: (to tune of "Far Above Cayuga’s Waters") Anarene High School, we love you, Love you oh so grand-- We will always be so loyal Loyal to a man... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Duane and Jacy join in, and the three LOUDLY SING the song as they drive down the street, all very happy in the front seat, Jacy’s hair blowing.

dialogues.speaker: THE THREE
dialogues.text: In defeat or victory We will always be true Dear old Archer, we love you And we'll always fight for you. Leroy’s car goes by, HONKING LOUDLY at them; it is filled with teenagers.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 27
dialogues.text: x! DRIVE-IN Al iT - DAY 28 All still in the convertible -- Jacy feeding Duane french fries -- cradling his head in her lap, RADIO PLAYING. JIMMIE SUE is getting orders.

dialogues.speaker: JACY
dialogues.text: You need a haircut. Jacy dangles a french fry and Duane gobbles it. Sonny notices a Cadillac approaching as he takes a big bite.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Better watch it. Here comes your mother. dacy quickly makes a little room between herself and Duane, trying to look demure. The Cadillac pulls up beside them. GENE FARROW is driving, scarcely looks at the boys. LOIS FARROW rolls down her window and fixes Jacy with a stern look.

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: Jacy, we’re having supper at home tonight. I’11 expect you in fifteen minutes, you hear? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: yo

dialogues.speaker: JACY
dialogues.text: (meek1ly ) Okay, Momma. I was just giving the boys a ride. Abilene drives up in his Mercury as the Cadillac pulls ou Gene gives him an ingratiating smile; Abilene nods, looks at Lois through his sunglasses. She looks at him through hers, both of them expressionless. Abilene gives her a small arrogant smile. Lois gives him the finger. Gene drives the car away.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: . fF. OW'S D: - N 29 The TV is on. Gene is dozing in his chair, a half- finished drink in one hand. After a moment, Lois gets up, a drink in her hand, and goes somewhat wearily up the stairs. 's OOM_— IT 30 Jacy is sitting on her bed, reading a movie magazine. On the dresser is a big picture of herself as "Football Queen.” A large bulletin board is covered with snapshots of herself and Duane plus a few mementoes (menu from the Junior Prom). Stuffed animals on the bedside table. Lois knocks, comes in and leans against the door. Jacy picks up a jar of blemish cream and goes to the dresser, where she cleanses her face. Her RADIO is playing.

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: I guess you hate me tonight.

dialogues.speaker: JACY
dialogues.text: (opening jar) Oh, Momma, you know I love you. But I love Duane, too, even if you don’t like it.

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: I don’t care, I’d just hate to see you marry him. You wouldn’t be rich any moré, and in about two months --

dialogues.speaker: JACY
dialogues.text: I don’t care about money -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: co

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) ~- he’d quit flattering you --

dialogues.speaker: JACY
dialogues.text: Not at all -- LoIs You’re pretty stupid then.

dialogues.speaker: JACY
dialogues.text: (shocked) You married Daddy when he was poor -- and he got rich, didn’t he?

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: (looking at china animals on bureau) I scared your Daddy into getting rich, beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: JACY
dialogues.text: (pouting) Well, if Daddy could do it, Duane could too.

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: Not married to you -- you’re not scary enough.

dialogues.speaker: JACY
dialogues.text: Well, you’re rich and you’re miserable -- I sure don’t want to be like you. LOIs Not much danger of that. (looks at Duane’s photo) Have you slept with him?

dialogues.speaker: JACY
dialogues.text: Momma! !

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: (amused) Well, we can go to the doctor sometime and we’ll arrange something so you won’t have to worry about babies -- You do have to be careful about that. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: her eyes. very young. 25.

dialogues.speaker: JACY
dialogues.text: (beyond helief) But Momma, it’s a sin, isn’t it? Unless you’re married? You know I wouldn’t do that.

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: (loudly) Oh, don’t be so mealy-mouthed-- * I thought if you slept with Duane * a few times you’d see there * isn’t anything magic about him, and then we can send you to a good school --

dialogues.speaker: JACY
dialogues.text: (plaintively} But I don’t wanna leave --

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: -~ where you’ll marry some wealthy kid -—- *

dialogues.speaker: JACY
dialogues.text: Why can’t I just stay here and go to college in Wichita Falls? LoIs (very straight) Because everything’s flat and empty here -- and there’s nothing to do. (picks up per- fume bottle) May I have some of this -- ?

dialogues.speaker: JACY
dialogues.text: (grudgingly) Help yourself -- don’t you have any?

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: Yes, but I feel like smelling good right now -- don’t you ever feel like doing anything right now? Lois touches herself behind the ears, puts her hands on her throat for a moment, savoring the scent, closes The cream is off Jacy’s face and she looks Lois softens. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: O LOIS
dialogues.text: You should leave your face just like that ~~ all you really need now is an eyebrow pencil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jacy looks blank and sleepy. Lois touches her hair.

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) Okay, good night. Jus’ remember, beautiful, everything gets old if you do it often enough. So if you want to find out about monotony real quick, marry Duane. Lois goes out. Jacy looks after her and goes sleepily toward her bed. 31 INT. FARROW DEN — NIGHT 31 Gene has gone. Lois freshens her drink, looks at the TV a moment, then picks. up the telephone and dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ABILENE’S VOICE Hello.

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: Abilehe? Were you asleep? ABILENE’S VOICE Naw.

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: Feel like company? ’ ABILENE’S VOICE Thought I’d drive out and see how my well is coming.

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: Well, drill hard. You’re better at oil wells anyway. She hangs up, and sits down at the TV with her drink. cuT TO: 32 xD PPER HOUSE = ¥ 32 VY Sonny stops his pickup in front of the house. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Quite nonchalant, he walks up the sidewalk, looks through doorpane and sees RUTH POPPER sitting in the living room, purse in her lap, looking rather drab in an unbecoming suit. She is listening to the RADIO. When he KNOCKS, she comes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Oh hello, Sonny, what do you want?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Coach said you needed a driver --

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: (startled) oh.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Didn’t he tell you I was coming?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: (disappointed) No, he didn’t mention it. I thought he was going to drive me himself. I guess he just couldn’t get off. She hands him the key chain and he goes to get their Plymouth out of the garage. She goes to turn off the radio.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. POPPER PLYMOUTH (OLNEY) — DAY 33 The wind is blowing, as they drive. Sonny is trying to think of something to say, looks over at her. She daubs at her eyes with a Kleenex. He looks forward again. Ruth opens her lipstick, holds it a minute and puts it back in her purse without using any.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. OLNEY CLINIC — DAY 34 Sonny is waiting in the car -- the RADIO playing. As Ruth comes out of the clinic, the wind blows her hair. Sonny opens the door for her; she is crying as she gets in, a strand or two of hair sticks to her wet cheek. They drive off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rev. 9/24/70 27A. 35 INT. POPPER PLYMOUTH (COUNTRY) — DAY 35 Sonny looks at her nervously. She is still crying, looking out at the bleak country. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Is it something bad?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: No. It’s just... something dreary. They drive on in silence. cur TO: Sonny pulls in, switches off the car. Ruth is looking dully ahead, at nothing. Sonny fiddles with the car keys, then goes around and opens the door for her.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Oh. . Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Here’s the keys. Guess I better ,get back to school.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: It was nice of you to drive me.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Beats sittin’ through Civics.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Wouldn’t you like to come in and have a Coke -- if you can stand me for a few more minutes. She looks at him apologetically, not taking the keys. The wind blows.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Okay. Reluctantly he follows her through the back door.and into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I hate these northers. INT. POPPER KITCHEN ~ DA’ 37 Small, messy, the breakfast dishes haven’t been washed or the table cleared. Ruth can barely find a place to set her purse. sonny doesn’t know whether to stand or sit. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Would you prefer milk? Just sit at the table -- or you can go right now if you like. I was just scared to be alone for a minute -- I’m sorry I made you come in.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: I‘’ll take a Coke. She gets him one, watches him drink; suddenly, to his amazement and disgust, she bursts out CRYING again, loudly, puts her head in her arms and sobs, body shak- ing. Sonny doesn’t even want to swallow what he has in his mouth. After a moment, she looks up and tries to stop.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: You’ll never forgive me, I know. Go on, you don’t have to stay any longer.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Thank you for the Coke. (pushes chair back) I guess you’1l be glad when basketball season is over.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Well, Coach probably don’t get to stay home much during football and basketball season. She lays down her napkin and looks at him as if for the first time. Stops crying.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: My God. You don’t know a thing about it, do you? She stares at him a long moment -- he gets uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: You better go on to basketball practice. He stands up, awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Well, thanks for the Coke. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods. He backs out and leaves. She looks after him unhappily.

As Jacy drives up in her convertible, LESTER MARLOW, a more citified boy, comes to her, bourbon flask in hand. She is uninterested in him.

dialogues.text: Hi, Jacy.

dialogues.speaker: JACY
dialogues.text: Oh, hi. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.text: Hell, you never feel well,

dialogues.speaker: LEGIT -
dialogues.text: At the pickup, Duane reaches under the front seat and gets a package, hands it to her shyly.

dialogues.speaker: JACY
dialogues.text: You mean my Christmas present?

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.text: Oh goodness. I haven’t got you anything yet.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: (starry-eyed) That’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: JACY
dialogues.text: I just couldn’t get loose for a minute to shop.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: (huskily) I hope you like it. Saved up for six months, to get it. Jacy unwraps the package -- it’s a wrist watch.

dialogues.speaker: JACY
dialogues.text: Oh, it’s jus’ beautiful. It’s just what I’ve been wanting. You're so sweet, spending all that money on me! (passionate kiss) Oh, you’re so sexy, Duane., I just wish I didn’t have to leave you tonight. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: O DUANE
dialogues.text: (surprised) You don’t!

dialogues.speaker: JACY
dialogues.text: (looking unhappy) Oh, I do too. I could just kill my mother --

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: JACY
dialogues.text: (might cry) ; She made me promise to go to a swimming party in Wichita, with what’s his name -- Lester Marlow | -- ‘cause his folks are so rich. |

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: Well, Goddamn! What kinda thing is that?! JACY i Don’t be mad at me, Duane. *

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: I ain’t mad at you, but Goddamn -- * can’t I come too? JACY. No, no! It’s all Lester’s fault * -- he keeps askin’ Momma -- and... *

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: Well, Goddamn -- !

dialogues.speaker: JACY
dialogues.text: All I wanna do is stay with the man I love. She kisses him, sprawls across his lap, takes one of his hands, guides it downward to her panties. Duane can hardly believe it. He hesitates, then proceeds. Jacy looks slightly martyred. Duane expects to be stopped, but isn’t -- grows bolder. Jacy seems about to give way, but when Duane tries to lay her down in the seat, she pushes him off. . gAcY DD No, no, Duane, I gotta go. * ~ I gotta go. *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Le Rev. Sl 10/2/70 She quickly gets out. Too flustered to stop her, Duane straightens hig shirt, then sees Lester step out on the hall porch. Jacy gets in Lester’s convertible. Duane rushes up the steps, grabs Lester by his lapels. Straightening her hair, Jacy watches.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: You chickenshit, you! What do you mean, asking my girl for a date? A corwd immediately begins to form around them. Lester is scared but tries to keep up a front.

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: Turn me loose.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: 1/11 turn you loose any time you’re ready to fight -- let’s have it out! As he puts up his fists, the SHERIFF looms between them, wearing cowboy hat cigar.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: Here now. None of that shit, boys. This here’s the Christmas season! (slaps Duane’s fist) Run on there, Wichita. I can’t stand here all night protectin’ your shoeshine. Lester hurries down to the convertible. Duane stands fuming, clenching his fists.

dialogues.speaker: JACY
dialogues.text: I don’t know what I’m going to do about him -- he’s just so crazy about me he doesn’t have good sense.

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: I’m not saying anything against Duane, but that’s a roughneck for you -~ they never are very sophisticated about these things. As the car pulls out, the Sheriff casually slaps Duane on the back.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFP
dialogues.text: Well, Merry Christmas!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: cy ed Rev. 10/6/70 52 INT. IERICAN_ LEGIO: —_ NIGH Sonny watches the dancers wistfully, goes into a game room where the Coach and some others are playing domi- noes.

dialogues.speaker: COACH
dialogues.text: Hell, you ask me, too bad we got elections coming up next year -—— now we got Harry Truman in there. ‘f it was me, I wouldn’t have no more.

dialogues.speaker: DOMINO PLAYER
dialogues.text: Well, I don’t know...

dialogues.speaker: DOMINO PLAYER
dialogues.text: Hey, you boys heard any jokes? I ain’t heard one in a month a Sundays.

dialogues.speaker: COACH
dialogues.text: Well, I heard one ‘bout a guy who stuck a big 01’ fat dill pickle... Sonny goes into the kitchen where Ruth is gathering empty punch cups and dirty paper plates into a large trash basket.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Hello, Sonny.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Want to help me?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Sure, (picks up cups)

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: You’re not dancing. Don’t you have a girlfriend?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: I did have. We broke up a couple months ago.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Why? Do you mind my asking?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: I was goin’ with Charlene Duggs -- she thought I got fresh with her -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: S2 CONTINUED
dialogues.text: —, 4 Ruth raises eyebrows, then heads for back door, carry- ing her basket; Sonny follows. *

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: (continuing) I never did, really. I guess we broke up ‘cause we didn’t like each other much to begin with. EXT. AMERICAN LEGION ALLEY -— NIGHT 53 The only light comes from a street lamp a block away.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I hope you’re not sad about it -- I don’t think Chariene’s nearly nice enough...

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: I didn’t see you dancing.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: No. I don’t dance much. They dump the cups into thé barrel, are suddenly very close. Ruth lifts her head and they kiss. Their mouths don’t hit just right and she holds his face and gently guides his mouth to hers.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Will you drive me to the clinic again -~ next week? *

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: You bet. He bends down to find her mouth and kisses so hard that her head is pushed back. A car turns the corner and they hastily break apart, picking up their wastebaskets awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Better not dawdle here. cUuUT TO:  Rev. 10/2/70 54 = B Y's. = 54 SANDY SHEEN, a ten-year-old, wearing a diving mask, is swimming around underwater observing a group of teenage boys and girls playing in the pool naked. One girl kicks him away and he surfaces as Jacy and Lester come timidly in the door.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Hey, look! New victims. The kids stop their water fights, swim over to the side of the pool. BOBBY SHEEN makes a big show of jumping out of the water and shaking Lester’s hands, grinning.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Hi, Jacy.

dialogues.speaker: JACY
dialogues.text: (meekly) Hi.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Glad you made it. We’re dressed informally, as you see. Big laugh. Bobby cocks his leg in acknowledgement. Jacy laughs thinly, trying not to look down. ANNIE- ANNIE MARTIN gets out of the pool, comes over, puts an arm around Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE-ANNIE
dialogues.text: Hi, Jacy -- you wanta join the club?

dialogues.speaker: JACY
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE-ANNIE
dialogues.text: Well, you gotta get undressed out there on the diving board --

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: So everybody gets to watch! Cheer from the others.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE-ANNIE
dialogues.text: We all did the first time.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: That’s the rule.

dialogues.speaker: LESTER
dialogues.text: Yeah, I did it last Easter. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: a pO ANNIE-ANNIE ; Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Everybody out for the strip show! 55 Everyone gets out of the pool and sits on the edge, 55 kicking their feet in the water. The room goes quiet except for the record playing. As dacy gets to the diving board, she hears Lester jump into the pool behind her. She gingerly climbs up on the diving board, so | nervous she can hardly keep her balance. ’ (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She is surprised to see Sandy beneath her.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Don’t pay any attention to Sandy -- he’s my little brother -- If he gooses you or anything, I’1l make him go to bed. The kids laugh, then quiet. Sandy dives underwater. Hesitantly, Jacy begins to strip.

dialogues.speaker: JACY
dialogues.text: Goodness, I hope I don’t fall off this thing.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Sandy can fish you out, if you do. Jacy strips -- just as she is taking off her bra the phonograph stops and clicks off. Sudden silence. Un- herved, she almost falls, has to sit down. Just beneath the board, Sandy surfaces, looking up at her. She yanks off her panties and indignantly throws them on his mask, jumps into the water. Everyone roars applause, jumps into the pool, starts splashing. Pleased with herself, Jacy holds onto the side and suddenly notices that she is still wearing Duane’s Christmas watch, puts it to her ear listens for a moment, concern in her face. dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Why’d Sam close the cafe?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: (abashed, gets out, scratching head) Oh, yeah, you all been gone, ain’t you -~ gone to Mexico. You don’t know ‘bout it.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: ‘Bout what?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Sam died yesterday morning.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: Died?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Yep -- quite a blow! Keeled over on one of the snooker tables. Had a stroke,

dialogues.speaker: KONNY
dialogues.text: Sam the Lion? Andy nods his head. Sonny and Duane look at him silently.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Yep, Sam’s dead. He was quite a feller. Sonny sits down on the curb, looks across the street at the dark poolhall. Duane kicks at one of Andy’s tires.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: (continuing) He had ‘is own way of doin’ things, that’s fer sure. They found his will -- craziest thing you ever heard. Left you the poolhall, Sonny -~ what do you think of that? (spits, scratch- ing gut) Sonny looks up, but the information barely registers. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Left Genevieve the cafe -- that’s the only thing he done made any sense. Left the picture show to old Miss Mosey. Hell, she’s too far gone to even run a popcorn machine -- (spits again, clears throat) And the craziest thing of all -- he left a thousand dollars to Joe Bob Blanton -- the preacher’s boy -- beats all I ever heard of. He could just as easy have left it to me. I deserve it least as much as that little ingorant bastard. They are all silent. The stop light blinks. Sonny sits staring at it. Andy sits on the fender.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Anyhow, it’s done. They’re burying him tomorrow. curT TO: GRAVE’ = 95 The graveyard is on a rough, gravelly hill, the wind is blowing loudly. Brother Blanton is praying. Joe Bob is near him. Sonny, Billy and Genevieve are standing together, watching the casket being lowered. Sonny’s sportscoat is too short at the wrists -- the wind blows Genevieve’s veil. She is crying. Duane is standing back in the crowd, so is Mr. Cecil. The Coach and Ruth are there, as are most of the town. She and Sonny exchange a look. Lois Farrow stands slightly apart from the rest. She is crying openly -- tears stream down her face. She wipes it with her glove. People start to move away. cuT TO:

dialogues.text: A bright, second-hand Mercury is parked in front of the poolhall, as a pickup full of ROUGHNECKS pulls up and Sonny jumps out, dirty and greasy. He looks in the car, sees Duane just sitting up, blinking in the sunlight. Sonny is uneasy. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SF SONNY
dialogues.text: Hey, Duane. Tanned dark, Duane gets out, wearing a Levi shirt with the arms cut out; they shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: Hi, buddy. Didn’t know you’d turned roughneck.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Got to make a livin’ somehow, so’s I can afford to keep the poolhall open. When’d ya get in?

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: ‘Bout two. Thought I’d surprise you. A moment of stiff silence; both grin, but they’re not really friendly. Sonny looks at the car.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: This yours?

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: Yeah, how about that? Thirty- eight thousand miles on her. Runs like new. {lights a cigarette) Wanna beer? * SONNY . Not me. *

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: (getting one from front seat) ‘S about all I eat for breakfast * anymore. *

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Sure is a nice car. *

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: I like to drive it so much I thought I’d run home for the weekend.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Duane drinks his beer and absently wipes bugs off the grill with a kerchief.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: Can‘t take too good care of a car like this. I wasn her every week.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Looks great. (pause) You heard about Joe Bob?

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: Yeah. I always Knew he was crazy.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Doctor said he aidn’t really do nothing ~~ just got her to take off her underpants.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: (skeptical) Yeah? Hey, you still secrewin’ that old lady?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: No. Yeah. Been kinda busy,

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: Seen old Jerry last week... said he thought you and Jacy’d been going together a little.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Yeah, we have, a little -- she’s been kinda bored... once and a while we eat Mexican food or something.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: Way I hear it that ain’t all you been eatin’.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Whoever told you didn’t know what he was talkin’ about. Sure, I been ggin’ with her, why not? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: I never said I blamed you for it. I don’t blame you much. I jus’ never thought you’d do me that way -- I thought we was still best friends.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: We are. What are you so mad for? I never done nothin’ to you.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: I guess screwin’ my girl ain’t nothing to you.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: I ain‘’t screwin’ her.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: The hell you ain/’t.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Well, I ain’t -- but she’s not your girl ahymore, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: She is my girl -~ I don’t care if wa did break up.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Hell, you don’t even live here anymore.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: Don’t make no difference -- 1/11 always live here. An’ I’m gonna get her back, I’m tellin’ you right now. She's gonna marry me one of these days, when I get a little more money...

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Why, she won’t marry you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: Sure she will! We always meant to get married.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: She’s goin’ off to college. I doubt I’1l ever get to go with her agin myself, once she gets off. I never saw what it could hurt to go with her this summer, though. She’s never gonna marry you.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: She is, by God! Don’t you tell me she won’t. She’ll never let you screw her, that’s for sure. Hell, I was just seein’ how honest you was -- I knew dacy wouldn’t let you screw her... You ain’t that good a cocksman. You never even screwed Charlene Duggs all the time you went with her.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: ‘Course I didn’t. You know why? * ‘Cause you had the pickup all the time Saturday nights... nobody Coulda screwed her in the time I had left.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: (smugly) I coulda screwed her in five minutes - I wouldn’t even need no pickup.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Yeahi? Wall, the only reason Jacy went with you long as she did was ‘cause you was in the backfield. I was in the Goddamn line!

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: What are you talkin’ about... me an’ her was in. love.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: You was! She likes me as good as she ever liked you.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: That’s a lie! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: I’1l stay all night with her, too, one of these nights. She’s done \ promised.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: You won't either!

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Yes, I will -- why shouldn’t I? she’s done told me you couldn’t even do it that time in Wichita * Falls -- What about that? * Enraged, Duane hits him with the bottle, catching him * on his eye. They slug at one another wildly, close, and struggle. Sonny’s eya bleeds, almost closed. Some men run out of the cafe; Genevieve behind them. Sonny Slowly collapses to his knees. Duane goes to hin, scared. Sonny passes out as the others run up.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. ‘ 1 = 137 sonny is in bed, one eye bandaged, trying to roll a cigarette. The RADIO is playing. A NURSE comes in.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: A lady’s down in the waiting room, Sent you this. She hands him a note; Sonny opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It reads! "May I come in and see you a little while? Ruth."

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE 139
dialogues.text: Sonny looks at the Nurse, unhappily.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: could you tell her I’m asleep?

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Sure, I could. But you’re not asleep. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: If I go to sleep right now will you tell her I’m asleep? Please?

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: All right. She goes out. Sonny lowers himself uneasily in the bed.

dialogues.text: Sonny sits behind the counter, eating a cheesburger. He looks drawn, but is dressed. The bandage on his eye is smaller. Billy is sweeping, Genevieve cleaning up the counter for him.

dialogues.speaker: GENEVIEVE
dialogues.text: That too cold?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Naw -~- ‘s great... I heard Duane joined the Army...

dialogues.speaker: GENEVIEVE
dialogues.text: Good place for ‘im, too.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: oh, he was jus’ holdin’ that * hottle -- didn’t mean to hit me * with it -- , *

dialogues.text: That boy’s always had meanness in him -- ‘couse Jacy’s jus’ the kinda girl brings out the meanness in a man. She looks him in the eye, but Sonny turns to his sandwich

dialogues.text: She’s just like her grandmother... * oh, I oughtn’t to talk about ‘en -- we was all good friends once -- Dan roughnecked with Gene Farrow. * Re and Lois lived in a little one * room place over the newspaper office.

dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

I wondered a lotta * times what would’ve happened if Dan * had made the strikes Gene made -- they offered the rig to Dan first -~- but then Dan Morgan never took a chance in his life -- *

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Do you wish y’all had made it?

dialogues.speaker: GENEVIEVE
dialogues.text: (tired smile) Oh, sure, I wish we’d made it.

dialogues.speaker: GENEVIEVE
dialogues.text: Oh, you wanna go over to Korea * and get yourself killed -- you ain’t got your senses back yet * -- what few you ever had. (going) Well, the cafe won’t run itself «+. you rest up now. I/11 bring you some dinner.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: (opening wallet) Thanks. Here’s for the cheeseburger.

dialogues.speaker: GENEVIEVE
dialogues.text: Okay... I’11 bring you change when I come back. She waves at Billy, who grins back. Sonny lays his wallet down. 142 EXT. POOLHALL — DAY 142 Jacy is just getting out of her car as Genevieve comes out. She looks at Jacy hard, which flusters her.
143 INT. POOLHALL — DAY 143 Billy brings Sonny a peanut pattie as Jacy comes in, looking sorrowful.

dialogues.speaker: JACY
dialogues.text: sonny?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: come on in. She comes over, gives him a big kiss... she looks at * Billy, who moves away warily; Jacy clearly doesn’t like * hin.

dialogues.speaker: JACY
dialogues.text: Oh, I was so worried I just had to see you -- *

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: I been missin’ you -- I’m a lot better’n I was.

dialogues.speaker: JACY
dialogues.text: You just can’t believe how famous we are -- we’re all anybody talks about in this town now --

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: (unhappily) I guess so.

dialogues.speaker: JACY
dialogues.text: I want us to get married.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: JACY
dialogues.text: I really do -- just as soon as you want to.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Get married?

dialogues.speaker: JACY
dialogues.text: Don’t you want to?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, yeah. She picks up the wallet Ruth gave Sonny and fondles it, * which makes him a little nervous.

dialogues.speaker: O JACY
dialogues.text: I bet the whole town’1l be knocked for a loop if we do. They’1l never : forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But ain’t you goin’ to college?

dialogues.speaker: JACY
dialogues.text: I don’t care about that -- I love you -- that’s more important. You were so dear to fight for me. My folks won’t like it, but we can run off.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: | They'll kill us -- kill me, anyhow.

dialogues.speaker: JACY
dialogues.text: Oh, they won’t. They’1l get over it. You’re workin’ for Daddy now anyway, and pretty soon they’11 love you as much as I do. (kisses him) Can we?

JACY’S = 145 * Sonny, wearing and eye patch, looks extremely happy. Jacy hair blows, her smile a little strained. Sonny puts his hand on her leg, under her skirt. She pushes it off, look at him nervously. The RADIO plays.

dialogues.speaker: JACY
dialogues.text: Don’t do that, Sonny.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Why not? We’re man and wife now -- we can do anything.

dialogues.speaker: JACY

dialogues.text: Well, I had to leave ‘em a note, so they wouldn’t be worried out of their minds.

dialogues.text: You shouldna done that.

dialogues.speaker: JACY
dialogues.text: I had to -- I figured they’d have to know some time.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Well, what could they get us for? We got a right to get married, ain’t we?

dialogues.speaker: JACY

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: I can take it off pretty soon... We'll be to Lake Texoma in two * hours -- have a room to ourselves. *

dialogues.speaker: JACY
dialogues.text: (annoyed) My goodness, you’re sitting so close I can barely drive. cur TO:

dialogues.text: The sun is setting as they drive by. INT. JACY’S CAR (OKLAHOMA ROAD #2) - DUSK 147° * Sonny is not sitting so close but Jacy looks even more nervous. A patrol car comes toward them. Jacy is hopeful, Sonny worried. It goes by. Jacy looks dashed; glancing in her rear-view mirror, she sees the car make a U-turn behind them. Her face brightens, but she feigns otherwise

dialogues.speaker: JACY
dialogues.text: Oh, goodness. Sonny looks back miserable. Police car pulls them over, lights flashing. PATROLMAN gets out. *

dialogues.text: Howdy -- what part of Texas y’all from?

dialogues.speaker: JACY
dialogues.text: Abalene.

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN
dialogues.text: Newlyweds, ain’t you? (they nod) Well, better follow me in. I think somebody’s a-lookin’ for you.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: We ain’t done a nothin’ wrong -- ain’t we got a right to get married? How can you arrest us, just like that? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN
dialogues.text: (peeling stick of gum) I ain’t arrestin’ you. JI just want you to come with me, till we find out. I don’t have no idea what you got a right to do.

dialogues.speaker: JACY
dialogues.text: (happily) I guess we better follow him, honey, I‘11 just be heart-broken if my folks have done this. The Patrolman goes to his car. Jacy kisses Sonny lightly as she puts the car in gear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gene Farrow is coming out with Lois, Sonny and jacy, whom grabs by the arm away from Sonny.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: Think I worked like a dog all my life so my daughter could end up in a poolhall?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: We was gonna get another apartment.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: I bet you was. Where’s your car keys, hon? Sniffing, Jacy fishes them out.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: It’s a hell of a note, a hell of a note.

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: Oh, shut up and take her home.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: It’s just a hell of a note.

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: I’m tired of this.

dialogues.speaker: GENE
dialogues.text: You bet I will. You take her car. So far as I’m concerned he can walk. Jacy looks back. Gene leads her to the Cadillac, spins of with her. Sonny stands watching her go off. Lois comes over, taps his arm.

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: Not much of a wedding night.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: No, not much of one. She brings out a little flask. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: (drinks) Here. Have a little bourbon--take the rest of it--might pick you up--I’ve gotta drive. Sonny sips from it several times. Lois grins. They walk back toward the car.

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: You won’t believe me, Sonny, but you’re lucky we got you clear of her quick as we did... you’d’ve been a lot better off stayin’ with Ruth Popper.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Does everybody know about that?

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: ‘Course. Sounded like a good thing te me, Kiddo--you shouldn’t’ve let Jacy turn your head.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: She’s prettier. I guess I shouldn’t’ve though. (pause) Guess I treated her terrible. LOIs I guess you did. They get in the car.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A LoIs That’1l be a big help if you mean to live your life in Anarene. I don’t, ae re

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: (shakes her head) Strange to have a daughter who wouldn't go through with her wedding night. When I was her age I'd go through with just ‘bout any old night.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: (sips bourbon) I quess TI can’t get in the Army now-- not with this eye. 154 EXT. RE IVER IDGE — NIGHT 154 Moonlight on the water; they drive into Texas again. 155 EXT. POOLHALL - NIGHT iss The car pulls up in front.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Sure wasn’t outta Texas very long. LOIs Well, Oklahoma’s not much of an improvement.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: (sips bourbon, pauses) *‘S not the same now. Nothing’s really been right since Sam the Lion died. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: (stares; sadly) . No, it hasn’t. (eyes water slightly) I get sad when I think of Sam for long. Did you know he had * beautiful hands?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: I guess you liked him, didn’t you? I guess everybody did.

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: No, it was more than that with me, honey -- I loved him. He loved me. Surprised, Sonny looks at her and it dawns on him. Looks at Sonny spill over.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Are you the one he used to take swimming? Out to the tank?

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: (looks at him; smiles) He told you about that, huh? Oh yeah, I was the one. (pauses ) If it hadn’ta been. for him, you know,. I’d have missed it -- whatever it is. I’d have been one of those Amity types that think bridge is the best thing life has to offer. He’s the only man I ever met who knew what I was worth. Sam the Lion. (smiles) Sam the Lion. Nobody knows where he got that name. I gave it to him -- one night. Just came to me. He was so pleased. I was twenty- two then -- can you imagine? briefly, holding back her tears; a few

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: (continuing) You know something, Sonny? It’s terrible only to find one man your whole life that knows what you’re worth. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOIS (cont’d) It’s just terrible--I wouldn’t be tellin’ you if it wasn’t. I’ve looked, too--you wouldn’t believe how I’ve looked. When Sam... was sixty-five years old he could jus’ walk into a room where I was and do more for me... (pause) Nobody was like him. (falls silent)

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: (hesitantly) Now I know why Sam liked you.

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: Loved me!

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: - Loved you, I mean.

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: Aw, do you? (looks at him, gently puts hand on his cheek) I can kinda see what he saw in you too. 155 She looks forward again, then back at him a moment, with reckless smile. Throws back his head and swallows, Lois is amused. He looks back, curiously. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: LOIS
dialogues.text: Nope. I/’11 just go on home.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Think I could learn to drink? He hands her back the flask.

dialogues.speaker: LOIS

dialogues.text: a

dialogues.text: Sonny, cleaned up and in his football jacket, is on the sidelines, holding one end of the first down chain. A middle-aged man named CHESTER holds the other, watching the warm-up intently. Coach Popper strides up and down the sidelines, waving and yelling, cheerleaders lead cheers, drum majors twirl. Sonny tries not to be de- * pressed. Tommy Logan runs by.

dialogues.text: That Logan boy’s a quarterback, now ain’t he? Boy, we finally got us a team. Didn’t back in your day, did they, Sonny?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: No, we wasn’t much good.

dialogues.speaker: CHESTER
dialogues.text: Well, you jus’ never learned the fundamentals. You Know, blockin’ and tacklin’. Not like this team. When was it you graduated?

dialogues.text: (unperturbed) You don’t mean it. Seems like longer that that since you and Duane played ball. Seen old Duane awhile ago -- he’s home on leave -- wearin’ his uniforn.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: (surprised, looks around) I ain’t seen him yet. As the Coach comes by, towel over shoulder, chawing 162 tobacco, he scarcely glances at Sonny, but shakes Chester’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: COACH
dialogues.text: (confident) Chester, see if y’can stretch that Goddamn thing a little. You know, a man never oughta cheat ‘cept in a good cause. (winks, goes on) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: cy

dialogues.speaker: CHESTER
dialogues.text: He’s a good ol’ bay, ain’t he?! * Everything grows quiet, players take off helmets 163 Coach takes off his cap; a hushed moment -- then the band begins the school song and whole school begins to SING:

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: "Anarene High School, we love you... Love you oh so grand. We will always be so loyal, Loyal to a man... Whether in defeat or victory, We will always be true. Dear old Anarene, we love you, And we’ll fight for you..." The song sweeps over the quiet field, the still town. Sonny moves his lips, but doesn’t really sing. Caught by a strong emotion, he loooks around the stands, at the players, the band. The song comes to an end. cur TO:

Gradually, the cars thin and Sonny and Billy walk on. EXT. CITY LAKE —- NIGHT 164A * Sonny and Billy walk past the quiet lake, Billy * sweeping occasionally.
