dialogues.text: ‘Ss ‘S HOUSE - 165 Cold, windy. Sonny drives the pickup to the shabby little unpainted three-room house, off an unpaved road; no walk. Duane’s Mercury is out front. Sonny KNOCKS on the door. MRS. JACKSON answers with some washing in her arms.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Hi, Mrs. Jackson -- Duane here?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. JACKSON
dialogues.text: That’s his car, ain’t it? He’s here if he ain’t walked off. She goes back inside. Sonny shuffles nervously on the porch. Duane appears in uniform, hair is slicked down. Nervous, he steps outside. Wind catches the screen door and SLAMS it back against the house; Duane shuts it.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: Hi... how you been?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Oh, pretty good.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: Been thinking all week I’d run into you.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Heard you was goin’ off to Korea. * Thought I’d better come by and see you ‘fore you got off.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: Glad you did. I’m takin’ the bus out, early in the morning. (lights cigarette adroitly) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Thought you might wanna go to the picture show -- Miss Mosey’s havin’ to close it -- tonight’s the last night.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: Yeah, might as well go -- hate to miss the last night. We can take the Mercury -- be the last chance I‘ll have to drive it for awhile. They head toward the car. INT. PIC SHOW -— NIGHT They sit stiffly, aware of one another, only eight or ten people in the theatre. Billy sits in the balcony watching. The western ends and Duane and Sonny get up and start out.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: That was a good movie.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Yeah. I seen it here before, once. Why don’t we run over to Wichita, drink a little beer.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: Okay, I got lots a time till mornin’.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: sure. Billy comes sweeping down the aisle. The boys grin at him as they pass. INT. HOW LOBBY — NIGH’ Miss Mosey is scraping out the popcorn machine, close to tears.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: So long, Miss Mosey.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: Sorry you’re closin’ the show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: an ww

dialogues.speaker: MISS MOSEY
dialogues.text: Nobody wants to come to shows no more -- kid baseball in the summer, school in the winter -- television all the time... If Sam had lived, I believe we could’ve kept it goin’. But I just didn’t have the know-how...

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: Won’t be much to do in town with the picture show closed.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: Well, so long.

dialogues.speaker: MISS MOSEY
dialogues.text: Duahe, you watch out now, overseas.

dialogues.speaker: EX
dialogues.text: Marlene Duggs is shivering at the curb. The boys glance at her as they pass. The wind is blowing trash from the gutters into the street. They get inte the Mercury, drive away. The picture show’s neon sign goes off. cuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 169
dialogues.text: ‘S_CAR ER CIT’ = 170 * The boys sit drinking beer. The MOTOR is running, RADIO on. Sonny rolls a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: Sure no women around tonight -- guess the next piece of ass I get’1l be yellow.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Wisht I was goin’ with you.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: (looks guilty) Hey, why don’t you look after the car for me? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Your Ma don’t need it?

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t want her drivin’ it, not better than she can drive. You might help her run the groceries home if you have the time.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: EXT.
dialogues.text: Trailways bus pulls in; Sonny gets Duane’s dufflebag from back seat, hands it to him. They stand a minute in the cold singing wind. Duane doesn’t look at him.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: Ever hear from Jacy?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: No, not a thing. She don’t get home much. Ain’t been back to town sincé August -- I guess she just stays in Dallas ail the time.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: Probably does. Must be lots to do, down in Dallas. A gust of wind hits them, they turn their backs to it.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: (continuing) I ain’t over her yet, you know. I ain’t over her yet -- it’s the damndest thing. That’s the only reason me and you got into it that time. Reckon she likes it down in Dallas?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Hard to say... maybe she does. Reckon you and her woulda got it all straightened out if I hadn’ta butted in?

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: Aw, no -- they’d’ve annulled me too, even if we had. You all never even got to the motel? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: No. DUANE. Well, better get on, before we both freeze. (hands him car * keys) Here’s the keys. So long, buddy. * They shake hands awkwardly, their eyes not quite meeting.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: So long, Duane -- be careful. I/11 take care of the Mercury for you. * About to step on the bus, Duane turns back. DUANE. See you in a year or two, if I don’t get shot. The bus drives away down the dusty street. Sonny walks slowly across the square toward the car. cur OUT:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy walks up with his broom, but the doors are locked. Mystified, a little sad, he goes across the street, sit on the curb, looking at the picture show.

Sonny comes shivering from the back room, goes to light * the old gas stove, sneezes several times. Lighting the jets, he HEARS a big cattle truck ROAR past in the streets, then, alarmingly loud, the SCREECH of air brakes. Sonny looks around, but goes on, lights the fires. Then goes to the door, looks out. Cc. POV) - DASH 175 * The big truck is stopped in front of the courthouse, several PEOPLE standing in front of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonny steps outside, curious. The cold wind makes him catch his breath. The Sheriff’s car pulls up and the Sheriff hurries to the front of the truck in his bathrobe. A cowboy, passing in a pickup, stops. Sonny turns to go back inside when he suddenly sees Billy’s broom lying in the street... he runs toward the truck, then jogs toward it, then slows to a walk. The Sheriff, a TRUCKER, two COWBOYS, a GAS STATION MAN, a PUMPER are gathered around Billy, who is lying in front of the truck, dead. The truck is full of Hereford yearlings, bumping one another., Numb, Sonny approaches the men, who look at Billy indifferently, spitting, shuffling.

dialogues.speaker: TRUCKER
dialogues.text: The sand was blowin’.

dialogues.speaker: PUMPER
dialogues.text: Yeah -- hard to see.

dialogues.speaker: TRUCKER
dialogues.text: I never noticed him, never figured nobody would be in the street. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: a GAS STATION MAN He was a kinda wandering ol’ kid -- always in the street. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TRUCKER
dialogues.text: What was he doin’ out there anyway, carryin’ that broom?

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: Aw, he weren’t doin’ nothin’. He was just an ol’ simple-minded kid -- never had no sense.

dialogues.speaker: COWBOY
dialogues.text: Sorta retarded, you know. Wasn’t your fault.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF
dialogues.text: Hell, no, Mister, I can see that.

dialogues.speaker: PUMPER
dialogues.text: He was just an’ ol’ dumb kid -- never was good for much.

dialogues.speaker: COWBOY
dialogues.text: Didn’t even know enough to get his ass out of the cold, morning like this.

dialogues.speaker: PUMPER
dialogues.text: Been me, I’da been home in the sack.

dialogues.speaker: COWBOY
dialogues.text: Let’s go to the cafe, Ira. I ain’t had no breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: TRUCKER
dialogues.text: I’d still like to know what he was doin’ luggin’ that broom aroun’ this time of day.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: He was sweepin’, you sons of bitches! He was sweeping! crying, Sonny grabs Billy under the arms, picks up hat, 1 and drags him - trying to run - across the street, lays him on the curb in front of the picture show; takes off h old football jacket and covers him. The men follow, slowly, looking at Sonny curiously. For several moments he looks at Billy’s cap, then lays it down next to hin, walks away.

dialogues.speaker: TRUCKER
dialogues.text: Y’all got some crazy kids in this town, you ask me. (spits again) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rev. 177
CONTINUED: (3) 177——«*

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFP
dialogues.text: Yeah, I don’t know what the times are comin’ to. Well, guess I better go call the undertaker -- Sonny has walked across the square to the poolhall, where he’s left the door open, the wind blowing in. The place looks empty, cold. He gets in Duane’s car, still crying. N' UANE’S C. cit IMITS) = DAY 178 Drives fast past the city limits sign, slows stops. The wind blows through the mesquite, over the grey ridges. Sonny sits a minute, then turns the car around. L ‘S CHER CITY JARE) — 179 Sonny drives into town. The truck is gone, the square empty again. ZL ‘SC POPPER = 180 Sonny drives to Ruth’s house and parks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonny walks numbly up the sidewalk, KNOCKS on the door. Ruth opens it in her bathrobe, looking very faded. Surprised, she makes a movement to hold her robe to- gether. Sonny barely glances at her.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Hi. (pauses ) Could I have a cup a’ coffee with you?

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: (reluctant) I guess. She holds the door open for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They go through the living room, into the disordered kitchen. Sonny sits at the table, while Ruth gets the coffee, moving awkwardly. A RADIO is playing in another room. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ot

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loe 182 LIGA.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: I’m sorry I’m still in my bathrobe. Sonny cannot look at her. As she begins to pour the coffee, her face tightens with anger. Suddenly, she flings Sonny’s coffee cup at the cabinet, then her own, then the coffee pot at the wall. It breaks. A great brown stain spreads over the wallpaper and drips to the linoleum. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: O RUTH
dialogues.text: What am I doing apologizing to you? Why am I always apologizing to you, you little bastard? Three months I been apologizing to you, without you even being here. I haven’t done anything wrong -- why can’t I quit apologizing. You’re the one ought to be sorry. I wouldn’t be in my bathrobe if it hadn’ta been for you -- I’da had my clothes on hours ago. You’re the one made me quit caring if I got dressed or not. I guess just becuase your friend got killed you want me to forget what you did an’ make it all right. I’m not sorry for you! You’d’ve left Billy, too, just like you left me. I bet you left him plenty a nights, whenever that girl whistled. I wouldn’t treat a dog that way! Sonny begins to say something.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: . (continuing) I guess you thought I was so old and ugly you didn’t owe me any explanations. Didn’t need to be careful of me. (pauses, struggling) There wasn’t anything I could do about you and her -- why should you be careful of me? You didn’t love me. Look at me! (sits opposite) Can’t you even look at me? Sonny looks, finally, but doesn’t know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: (continuing) Y’see? You shouldn’t have come here. I’m around that corner now. You’ve ruined it and it’s lost completely. Just your needing me won’t make it come back. io Ruth’s hands are nervously clasped on the table. Sonny YJ reaches out and takes one of them. She is startled and stiff, but Sonny holds on and in a moment, disconcerted, she lets him hold it. His fingers weave through hers. Ruth looks at him, cautiously. He sits blankly. Uv (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: With the fingers of her other hand, she begins to smooth the hair at the back of his wrist, then turns his hand over, traces the lives in his palm up to the wrist, press the tips of her fingers against the blue viens at his wrist and goes upward under the sleeve of his shirt. All at once tears spring in her eyes. She takes Sonny’s hand and presses it to her throat, to her wet face. She is on the verge of saying something fine, something wise or brave or beautiful, gasps with it, squeezes his hand, loses the words. After a moment, quieter, she puts his hand on the table, strokes his fingers with hers. She notices his shirt collar is wrinkled, under his jacket, and tenderly reaches to straighten it.

dialogues.speaker: RUTH
dialogues.text: Never you mind, honey... never you mind. PULL AWAY from them slowly.

dialogues.speaker: E
dialogues.text: The street is empty, and so is the square. The wind is blowing, raising the dust, and the picture show is closed FADE OUT.
